nukleonrus wrote:
> Thank you for advices but crawl.log seems to be a bottleneck too. Is there a way to minimize its size?

Not really.

At checkpoints, logs are rotated, so you could compress or move away 
early parts of the log.

We have occasionally considered auto-compressing the crawl.log like the 
recovery log, but it is fairly important for the crawl.log to be easily 
randomly accessible, and for the last few lines to be precise 
(especially in the aftermath of a crash, which might have prevented 
compression buffers from being flushed). Also, in our operations we 
consider storage of metadata like log lines to be very cheap (especially 
with respect to the content, which is many magnitudes larger), so don't 
really optimize it for size.

- Gordon @ IA
